Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the effectiveness of naturally acquired COVID-19 by stating it is 99.9982% effective, without providing sufficient evidence or comparing it to the effectiveness of vaccines.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the assertion that naturally acquired COVID-19 is 99.9982% effective.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that naturally acquired COVID-19 is better than vaccination without providing evidence or considering the risks associated with contracting the virus.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the alternative explanation that vaccines offer immunity without the risk of getting sick, which is the entire purpose of vaccination.
